messages.subject: Re: reply to Ron...
messages.msgSnippet: Thanks, Ron.  Very good advice.  I will remember it! Steve ... opinion on this issue! ... you, if asked. It is interesting to see the shinsa team handling iron
messages.messageBody:
Thanks, Ron. Very good advice. I will remember it!

Steve


--- In nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com, "Ron Hartmann" <
swords@u...> wrote:
> >It's rather surprising to think that there is >such a variety of
opinion on this issue!
>
> Yes, I think you will get enough opinions to thoroughly confuse
you, if asked. It is interesting to see the shinsa team handling
iron tsuba with gloves--I understand this with kinko tsuba, but
iron? Over the years it seems each authority had his own
opinion on what was best for caring for or handling iron tsuba. In
reality, I think it comes down to common senese. If you have a
"treasure" iron tsuba, maybe handling it with gloves (or at least
with great respect) goes along with placing it in a quality tsuba
box for safe keeping or display. It becomes more a matter of
respect than safe keeping. If none of these iron plates were ever
handled over the centuries, they probably wouldn't have that
wonderful color and "feeling" we all treasure today.
>
> Ron
> STL

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] reply to Ron...
messages.msgSnippet: ... Yes, I think you will get enough opinions to thoroughly confuse you, if asked. It is interesting to see the shinsa team handling iron tsuba with gloves--I
messages.messageBody:
>It's rather surprising to think that there is >such a variety of opinion on this issue!

Yes, I think you will get enough opinions to thoroughly confuse you, if asked. It is interesting to see the shinsa team handling iron tsuba with gloves--I understand this with kinko tsuba, but iron? Over the years it seems each authority had his own opinion on what was best for caring for or handling iron tsuba. In reality, I think it comes down to common senese. If you have a "treasure" iron tsuba, maybe handling it with gloves (or at least with great respect) goes along with placing it in a quality tsuba box for safe keeping or display. It becomes more a matter of respect than safe keeping. If none of these iron plates were ever handled over the centuries, they probably wouldn't have that wonderful color and "feeling" we all treasure today.

Ron
STL
----- Original Message -----
From: steven
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Thursday, September 23, 2004 8:40 PM
Subject: [nihontostudy] reply to Ron...


Hi Ron,

Hmmm... I'd heard that even touching iron tsuba wasn't such a good
idea due to this leaving oils which would eventually invite red
rust...but maybe this isn't the case(?)... It's rather surprising
to think that there is such a variety of opinion on this issue!
Thanks for the input!

Steve

messages.messageBody:
Hi Ron,

Hmmm... I'd heard that even touching iron tsuba wasn't such a good
idea due to this leaving oils which would eventually invite red
rust...but maybe this isn't the case(?)... It's rather surprising
to think that there is such a variety of opinion on this issue!
Thanks for the input!

Steve
